repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Better Education through
            Reformed Management and Universal Teacher Upgrading
            (BERMUTU) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Better Education through
            Reformed Management and Universal Teacher Upgrading
            (BERMUTU) Project for Indonesia were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: improving teaching quality and performance
            requires an articulated, focused, and holistic approach,
            just like the one included in BERMUTU. Ministry of Education
            and Culture (MoEC) being in the driver seat owning and
            implementing the program without the need of parallel
            structures greatly contributed to the satisfactory
            achievement of the stated project development objectives
            (PDOs) and ensured technical, institutional, and financial
            sustainability of BERMUTU's key interventions after the
            closing date. BERMUTU-follow up programs currently
            implemented by MoEC and some districts, largely navigating
            in new and unchartered territory will greatly benefit from a
            continued technical support from international and
            multilateral donors providing sound technical advice and
            linkages with worldwide best practices.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Better Education through
            Reformed Management and Universal Teacher Upgrading Project
            (BERMUTU) : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Better
            Education through Reformed Management and Universal Teacher
            Upgrading Project (BERMUTU) for Indonesia is to contribute
            to the improvement of the overall quality and performance of
            teachers through enhancing teachers' knowledge of
            subject matter and pedagogical skills in the classroom. As a
            follow up to the mid-term review of the project, the
            proceeds of the said credit, loan and grant were reallocated
            (dated November 23, 2011) to reflect the actual disbursement
            as of 2010 and revised disbursement plan 2011-2013. However,
            the Government of Indonesia changed the official exchange
            rates used for budgeting purposes from IDR 9,200/USD in
            FY2011 to IDR 8,800/USD in FY 2012. As a result, the actual
            expenditures of each category up to December 2011, and the
            budget allocation in FY 2012 (both in USD currency) are
            slightly different from the agreed disbursement plan for
            2011-2013 (used as a basis for the amendment of the proceeds
            in November 23, 2011). This especially affected the
            allocation for the working group program (under category 4)
            increasing by USD 566,898, or about one percent. This amount
            is to be covered by using the unallocated (category 7) and
            some efficiency of categories 2, 3 and 5. The reallocation
            of proceeds is to accommodate such changes in the exchange
            rates and has been incorporated into the revised
            disbursement plan for the remaining two years of the project
            implementation (2012-2013). This reallocation of proceeds is
            necessary to properly finance the implementation of the
            project activities and meet the agreed project development objectives.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Better Education through
            Reformed Management and Universal Teacher Upgrading Project
            (BERMUTU) : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Better
            Education through Reformed Management and Universal Teacher
            Upgrading Project (BERMUTU) is to contribute to the
            improvement of the overall quality and performance of
            teachers through enhancing teachers' knowledge of
            subject matter and pedagogical skills in the classroom. As
            part of the mid-term review, the Government and the Bank
            team have jointly reviewed the actual expenditures of each
            loan, credit and grant category during the first half of the
            project period (2008-2010). There are some shifts from the
            original cost calculations, primarily that the number of
            teachers participating in the working group program (under
            Category 4) has substantially exceeded project design
            estimates. This substantial increase has a flow-on effect
            for the budget required for supporting activities such as
            training of trainers and master teachers, workshops and
            program management under category three. The reallocation of
            proceeds reflects these changes in the scope of activities
            and is detailed in the revised disbursement plan for the
            remaining three years (2011-2013). This is necessary to
            properly finance project activities and meeting agreed
            project development objectives.

            Project (BERMUTU) : restructuring : Main report
